segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 22
segments.en: Linked Discourses 22

segments.pli: 6. Upayavagga
segments.en: 6. Involvement

segments.pli: 59. Anattalakkhaṇasutta
segments.en: 59. The Characteristic of Not-Self

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana.

segments.pli: Tatra kho bhagavā pañcavaggiye bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: There the Buddha addressed the group of five mendicants:

segments.pli: “bhikkhavo”ti.
segments.en: “Mendicants!”

segments.pli: “Bhadante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.
segments.en: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

segments.pli: Bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: The Buddha said this:

segments.pli: “Rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, anattā.
segments.en: “Mendicants, form is not-self.

segments.pli: Rūpañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ rūpaṃ ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca rūpe:
segments.en: For if form were self, it wouldn’t lead to affliction. And you could compel form:

segments.pli: ‘evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
segments.en: ‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that!’

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṃ anattā, tasmā rūpaṃ ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati rūpe:
segments.en: But because form is not-self, it leads to affliction. And you can’t compel form:

segments.pli: ‘evaṃ me rūpaṃ hotu, evaṃ me rūpaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
segments.en: ‘May my form be like this! May it not be like that!’

segments.pli: Vedanā anattā.
segments.en: Feeling is not-self …

segments.pli: Vedanā ca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ vedanā ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca vedanāya:
‘evaṃ me vedanā hotu, evaṃ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.
Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, vedanā anattā, tasmā vedanā ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati vedanāya:
‘evaṃ me vedanā hotu, evaṃ me vedanā mā ahosī’ti.
Saññā anattā … pe …
segments.en: Perception is not-self …

segments.pli: saṅkhārā anattā.
segments.en: Choices are not-self …

segments.pli: Saṅkhārā ca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissaṃsu, nayidaṃ saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṃvatteyyuṃ, labbhetha ca saṅkhāresu:
‘evaṃ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṃ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.
Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, saṅkhārā anattā, tasmā saṅkhārā ābādhāya saṃvattanti, na ca labbhati saṅkhāresu:
‘evaṃ me saṅkhārā hontu, evaṃ me saṅkhārā mā ahesun’ti.
Viññāṇaṃ anattā.
segments.en: Consciousness is not-self.

segments.pli: Viññāṇañca hidaṃ, bhikkhave, attā abhavissa, nayidaṃ viññāṇaṃ ābādhāya saṃvatteyya, labbhetha ca viññāṇe:
segments.en: For if consciousness were self, it wouldn’t lead to affliction. And you could compel consciousness:

segments.pli: ‘evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ hotu, evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
segments.en: ‘May my consciousness be like this! May it not be like that!’

segments.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṃ anattā, tasmā viññāṇaṃ ābādhāya saṃvattati, na ca labbhati viññāṇe:
segments.en: But because consciousness is not-self, it leads to affliction. And you can’t compel consciousness:

segments.pli: ‘evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ hotu, evaṃ me viññāṇaṃ mā ahosī’ti.
segments.en: ‘May my consciousness be like this! May it not be like that!’

segments.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave,
segments.en: What do you think, mendicants?

segments.pli: rūpaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: Is form permanent or impermanent?”

segments.pli: “Aniccaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “Impermanent, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

segments.pli: “Dukkhaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “Suffering, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

segments.pli: ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’”ti?
segments.en: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

segments.pli: “No hetaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Vedanā …
segments.en: “Is feeling permanent or impermanent?” …

segments.pli: saññā …
segments.en: “Is perception permanent or impermanent?” …

segments.pli: saṅkhārā …
segments.en: “Are choices permanent or impermanent?” …

segments.pli: viññāṇaṃ niccaṃ vā aniccaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “Is consciousness permanent or impermanent?”

segments.pli: “Aniccaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “Impermanent, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

segments.pli: “Dukkhaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “Suffering, sir.”

segments.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
segments.en: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

segments.pli: ‘etaṃ mama, esohamasmi, eso me attā’”ti?
segments.en: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

segments.pli: “No hetaṃ, bhante”.
segments.en: “No, sir.”

segments.pli: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
segments.en: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

segments.pli: Yā kāci vedanā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattā vā bahiddhā vā … pe … yā dūre santike vā, sabbā vedanā: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
segments.en: Any kind of feeling at all …

segments.pli: Yā kāci saññā … pe …
segments.en: Any kind of perception at all …

segments.pli: ye keci saṅkhārā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā … pe … ye dūre santike vā, sabbe saṅkhārā: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
segments.en: Any kind of choices at all …

segments.pli: Yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
segments.en: You should truly see any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ passaṃ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati.
segments.en: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

segments.pli: Nibbindaṃ virajjati; virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṃ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṃ hoti.
segments.en: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.

segments.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”

segments.pli: Idamavoca bhagavā.
segments.en: That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamanā pañcavaggiyā bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanduṃ.
segments.en: Satisfied, the group of five mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne pañcavaggiyānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsūti.
segments.en: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of the group of five mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.

segments.pli: Sattamaṃ.

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Benares,…

suttaplex.blurb: In the Deer Park at Varanasi the Buddha teaches the famous second discourse, on not-self with regard to the aggregates, to the group of five monks. At the conclusion, they become perfected ones.
